text:
Amazing Spaces opens up a bach on sleds COLLEEN HAWKES Last updated 20:30, February 23 2017 SIMON DEVITT 
The Whangapoua hut on sleds, designed by Crosson Architects, wowed architect and Amazing Spaces presenter George Clarke. 
Amazing Spaces presenter George Clarke is back in one of his favourite places in the world – the Coromandel Peninsula. 
His road trip on the most recent show takes him to Whangapoua where he has found a tall, timber box beside the sea that gives nothing away on the outside. 
We have seen architect Ken Crosson's own bach, which is not dissimilar – albeit it on a larger scale – so we have a fair idea how this might work. TVNZ 
Whangapoua bach is one out of the box. 
And this house is also by Crosson Architects, so we're not too surprised to see it that it peels open like an orange. But this bach has another tricky feature – it sits on two gigantic oak beams that can be pulled by a tractor, so it is essentially a hut on sleds. If the coast erodes or the sea rises, the house can be moved. 
READ MORE 
At the touch of a button, the front wall folds up to create an overhang. 
Clarke cleverly calls it a classic example of "blue-sky thinking". 
The interior is even more inspiring. Lined in timber, with floor-to-ceiling bookcases stretching right up the double-height void, the hut is guaranteed to keep you amused even when it rains. 
Clarke says, "A lot of work has gone into this to make it look simple, but my word, it's worth it." And who could fail to be charmed by the half-ton wall that folds up like a piece of origami, and the trap-door onto the roof terrace, which makes Clarke feels like a lifeguard on the watchtower. SIMON DEVITT 
Shutters can also be opened, creating awnings above the windows at the side of the house. 
We also get to see the next stage of the presenter's own project – a rotating house with a different "room" on each wall. Now they have mastered the art of the rotation, all that remains is to see how they deal with the furniture, not to mention the food and drink. 
It's all suitably mad, but oddly compelling. 
Amazing Spaces screens on TVNZ 1 on Thursdays at 7.30pm. SIMON DEVITT 
While the bach is currently anchored in place, it could be moved by tractor. - Stuff
